name: A letter from a listener in March 1933 responding to the first “fireside chat.”

citation.text: Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration.
“J. F. Bando letter to Franklin D. Roosevelt in reaction to first Fireside Chat,” Digital Public Library of America, https://dp.la/item/5dcd08bb66f691c30fb77e5fae83156a.

text:
Secretary to the President

The White House

Washington, D.C.


Dear Sir:

Being a citizen of little or no consequence I feel the utter futility of writing to the 
President at a time such as this, but I trust you will accept this letter in the spirit in 
which it was written.

For me to sit down to write to any public official, whoever he may be, it must be 
prompted by a very special and appealing occasion or personality. That happened 
last evening, as I listened to the Presidents [sic] broadcast. I felt that he walked into 

my home, sat down and in plain and forceful language explained to me how he was 
tackling the job I and my fellow citizens gave him. I thought what a splendid thing it 
would be if he could find time to do that occasionally. 


Needless to say, such forceful, direct and honest action commands the respect of all 
Americans, it is certainly deserving of it.

My humble and sincere gratitude to a great leader. May God protect him.

Respectfully,

J. F. Bando
